bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, January 15, 1900
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 43, Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Jan. 15, 1900.

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D 6 '00 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say, that neither the city, nor the Government, has a health officer; nor a board of health; from whom or which we can obtain the desired Sanitary information, demanded in the weekly Sanitary Report, to the Secretary of the Treasury. It is with the ulinost regelance, that we are enabled to make any trustworthy report. We obtain our information, principally,
principally, by a constant watch, inquiry, funeral notices, and processions. In these it is very difficult for us to learn of the diseases or cuases of death.
The above, I have not communicated to the Secretary of the Treasury.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General.
